Expectation1: Assemble and construct wooden frameworks, furniture, or cabinetry
Situation1: The carpenter is building custom cabinetry and needs to collaborate with other construction professionals to complete the project on time
Situation2: Multiple ID types are acceptable, and spare cards can still be fetched later in the day.
Story: I wiped the sweat from my brow as I measured the last plank for the custom cabinetry. The contractor was clear: everything had to be ready by the end of the day, and the electrician was already waiting for me to finish so he could start his work. My phone buzzed—a reminder to vote. I’d planned to go during my lunch break, but the hinges for the cabinet doors had arrived late, and now every minute counted. I knew I needed to bring my ID, but I’d left my main card at home. I had a backup in my wallet, but I wasn’t sure if it would be accepted. If not, I’d have to leave the site again later, risking the project’s timeline. The team was counting on me to keep things moving, but I also felt the weight of my civic duty. My mind raced, torn between the expectations of my craft and my responsibility as a citizen, feeling the pressure build as I tried to figure out how to be both a reliable carpenter and a responsible voter.
